title: Ghost Tour Pub Crawls: A Guide
content:
Ghost tour pub crawls sit at the intersection of folklore and nightlife. They're not about chasing evidence or jump scares. They're about stories—told where people have been gathering, drinking, and occasionally dying for centuries. The first haunted pub crawl I joined wasn't rowdy or chaotic. It was relaxed, conversational, and surprisingly educational. The alcohol was optional. The history wasn't.

How do haunted pub crawls work?

A haunted pub crawl is a guided walking tour that combines ghost stories with stops at historic bars or taverns. Groups move together from location to location while a guide explains the history of each site and any paranormal stories associated with it. Most crawls last two to three hours and include three to five stops. Time inside each bar is structured but flexible, allowing participants to order drinks or simply listen and move on.

What kind of stories will you hear?

Stories on pub crawls tend to focus on former patrons, bartenders, political figures, and events tied to the buildings themselves. Fires, duels, unsolved murders, and prohibition-era crime come up often. What sets these tours apart is context. Guides explain how taverns functioned historically as meeting places, courtrooms, and even makeshift hospitals—roles that naturally produce dark stories without exaggeration.

Are drinks included?

In most haunted pub crawls, drinks are not included in the ticket price. Participants usually purchase their own beverages at each stop, which keeps the experience flexible for non-drinkers. Some tours may offer drink specials or suggested orders tied to the location's history, but alcohol is optional. I've taken pub crawls where several participants never ordered a drink and still enjoyed the experience fully.

What's the atmosphere like?

The atmosphere is typically social but controlled. These tours are not bar-hopping parties. Groups stay together, guides manage pacing, and storytelling remains the focus. That said, energy levels are higher than on traditional walking ghost tours. Conversations flow more freely, and the setting encourages questions and shared reactions—especially in older pubs with creaking floors and low ceilings.

Pub crawls vs other tour formats

Compared to other ghost tour formats, pub crawls offer a distinct experience:
  • Walking tours cover more locations but don't include the indoor social element
  • Investigation tours focus on equipment and evidence rather than atmosphere
  • Cemetery tours are more contemplative and solemn
  • Bus tours cover more distance but lack the intimate pub setting

Where are the best haunted pub crawls?

Haunted pub crawls work best in cities with long drinking traditions and preserved historic bars.
  • London offers centuries-old pubs where documented history overlaps with legend.
  • Dublin combines folklore, rebellion-era history, and pubs that predate modern plumbing.
  • New Orleans blends haunted lore with an open-container culture that makes pacing easier and stops more atmospheric.
  • Boston offers colonial-era taverns with Revolutionary War connections.
  • Edinburgh combines pub stops with underground vault visits.

Who should do a haunted pub crawl?

Haunted pub crawls are ideal for travelers who want ghost stories without heavy intensity. They work well for couples, small groups, and visitors who prefer social experiences over quiet investigation. Solo travelers often find pub crawls particularly comfortable—the social setting makes it easy to chat with other participants. They're less suitable for families with kids, serious paranormal investigators, or anyone looking for a sober, academic experience. Skeptics who enjoy history and atmosphere often find pub crawls surprisingly rewarding.

What to know before booking

Read reviews to gauge the balance between drinking and storytelling. Some tours lean heavily toward nightlife; others maintain a clear educational focus. Our guide on how to spot a bad ghost tour applies here too—quality varies significantly. Wear comfortable shoes since you'll still be walking between stops. See our what to wear guide for practical advice.

Practical Takeaway

Ghost tour pub crawls are about ambiance, not evidence. If you enjoy history told in informal settings and like the option of a drink along the way, they're one of the most enjoyable ghost tour formats available.
